title: Multiple Failed Authentication Events
description: Multiple failed logon attempts detected from a single external IP targeting numerous user accounts. Investigate whether this is an active attack or a misconfigured service.

alert.title: Multiple Failed Logon Attempts from Single Source

fields.Detection Rule: Multiple Failed Logons from Single IP Exceeding Threshold

investigation_actions.label: Review the failed logon event details

result.content: 18 failed logon attempts (Event ID 4625) from 203.0.113.45. Failure reason: 'Unknown user name or bad password' (Status 0xC000006D). Attempts spaced ~16 seconds apart targeting different accounts sequentially. Logon type 3 (Network) via HTTPS against OWA endpoint. Pattern is highly consistent — automated tooling suspected.

IP 203.0.113.45 geolocates to a VPS hosting provider in Romania. Not associated with any known corporate VPN, partner, or third-party service. No previous logon history from this IP in the past 90 days. ASN belongs to a budget hosting provider commonly used for ephemeral infrastructure.

investigation_actions.label: Check for successful logons from this IP

result.content: No successful logons (Event ID 4624) from 203.0.113.45. All 18 attempts failed. However, attempts are still ongoing — 2 additional failures logged in the last 60 seconds while investigating.

investigation_actions.label: Review the list of targeted accounts

result.content: Targeted accounts follow the organization's naming convention (first.last): jsmith, mwilliams, rbrown, kjohnson, dlee, agarcia, tmartin, cwilson, pthompson, janderson, mtaylor, sclark, bwright, nhall, kallen, dyoung, lking, jwalker. Includes 2 accounts with admin privileges (jsmith-admin, mwilliams-admin). No service accounts targeted.

investigation_actions.label: Analyze password patterns in failed attempts

result.content: Authentication logs show a small set of passwords rotated across all 18 accounts: 'Summer2026!', 'Password1!', 'Welcome123', 'Company2026!'. Each account attempted with 1 password before moving to the next account — classic credential spray pattern designed to stay below per-account lockout thresholds.

investigation_actions.label: Check IP against threat intelligence feeds

result.content: IP 203.0.113.45 flagged by 3 threat intel feeds. Associated with brute force and credential spray campaigns over the past 2 weeks. Reported by 6 other organizations for similar activity. Listed on AbuseIPDB with a confidence score of 92% malicious.

3 of 18 targeted accounts are currently locked out (jsmith, rbrown, cwilson) — these had recent failed logons from legitimate users that combined with the spray attempts to exceed the 5-attempt lockout threshold. Remaining accounts have 1-3 failed attempts recorded. Attacker appears to be using only 1 attempt per account per pass to avoid triggering lockouts.

investigation_actions.label: Review firewall logs for source IP activity

result.content: Firewall shows 203.0.113.45 has been active for approximately 2 hours. Initial activity was port scanning (443, 3389, 8443) starting at 07:20 UTC. RDP attempts (3389) were blocked by firewall policy. OWA endpoint (443) was reachable and is where the credential spray is focused. No other internal resources accessed.

decisions.label: Block source IP at firewall and escalate to IR team — active credential spray attack
decisions.feedback: Correct! This is an active credential spray attack from a known malicious IP. Immediate IP blocking stops the ongoing attack, and escalation ensures the IR team can assess whether any credentials were compromised, reset locked accounts, and hunt for related activity.

decisions.label: Escalate to IR team for investigation — do not block IP yet
decisions.feedback: Partially correct. You correctly identified this as a real threat requiring escalation, but the attack is actively ongoing. Delaying the IP block allows the attacker to continue attempting passwords. With no legitimate business reason for this IP, an immediate block carries no risk and stops the bleeding while IR investigates.

decisions.label: Investigate whether a misconfigured service or application is causing the failed logons
decisions.feedback: Incorrect. The evidence clearly points to an external attack, not a misconfigured service: the source is an unknown foreign VPS IP, the targets are user accounts (not service accounts), and the pattern is consistent with automated credential spray tooling. Investigating a service account theory wastes time while the attack continues.

decisions.label: Close — likely a misconfigured application generating failed logon noise
decisions.feedback: Incorrect. This is not application noise. The sequential targeting of 18 different user accounts from an external VPS IP with common passwords is a textbook credential spray attack. Closing this alert leaves the attack uncontained and the attacker free to continue.

decisions.label: Close as false positive — failed logons are routine
decisions.feedback: Incorrect. While individual failed logons are common, 18 different accounts targeted sequentially from a single foreign IP in 5 minutes is not routine activity. This is an active credential spray attack that requires immediate containment.
